head.title: Phone Equipment Manufacturer May Be Sold

hedline.hl1: Phone Equipment Manufacturer May Be Sold

body.head.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED
Sorkin, Andrew Ross; De La Merced, Michael J

block.p: Avaya was near a deal last night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion in the latest buyout in the telecommunications industry, according to people briefed on the sale.

The two private equity firms appear to have bested a rival bid from Nortel Networks and a deal may be announced as early as today, those people said. But they cautioned that the talks were ongoing and that Nortel could field a higher 11th-hour bid.

Avaya was near a deal last night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion in the latest buyout in the telecommunications industry, according to people briefed on the sale.

The two private equity firms appear to have bested a rival bid from Nortel Networks and a deal may be announced as early as today, those people said. But they cautioned that the talks were ongoing and that Nortel could field a higher 11th-hour bid.
The firms are expected to pay about $17 per share, the people said. Avaya's shares closed Friday at $16.08.

Speculation about a buyout first arose two weeks ago, when the company unexpectedly postponed a meeting with analysts without offering an explanation or setting a new date. An Avaya spokeswoman would not comment.

Avaya, which was once a division of Lucent Technologies and AT&T before that, is one of the nation's top makers of phone equipment, rivaling Cisco, Nortel and Alcatel-Lucent in providing Internet-based communications to corporations. Much of its business focuses on upgrading companies to voice networks that can also offer video and data services.

Avaya draws almost a third of its revenue from its long-term maintenance contracts, though the company has warned that as those agreements expire, its customers have the leverage to demand lower fees.

The company, which was spun off from Lucent in October 2000, suffered in 2002 as the dot-com bubble burst. But its financial health has rebounded so strongly that a Merrill Lynch analyst recently described Avaya as an ideal buyout candidate.

In its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 2006, the company reported net profit of $201 million on revenue of $5.12 billion, and it is virtually debt-free. The company, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., has about 20,000 employees.

The move comes amid heavy deal-making in the telecommunications sector. Last month, Alltel, the wireless service provider, agreed to a $27.5 billion buyout by Texas Pacific and a unit of Goldman Sachs.

Analysts have predicted consolidation in the telecommunications equipment sector. Mergers among phone companies have amplified their size and purchasing power, while low-cost Asian companies have squeezed the profits of their Western counterparts. Last year, Alcatel and Lucent agreed to merge in an $11.6 billion deal, which many analysts say forced players like Avaya and Nortel to ally to stay competitive.
Some analysts had seen an Avaya-Nortel pairing as a good fit. But the companies' overlap in product offerings make integration difficult, analysts said.
